Problem:
Consider a linear transformation system where initial data points are mapped in a complex plane according to the function \\\( z(t) = z_0 e^{i\\omega t} \\\), where \\\( i \\\) is the imaginary unit, \\\( \\omega \\\) is a constant, and \\\( t \\\) is time. We examine the effect of another transformation \\\( h(z) = z e^{\\alpha t} \\\) introduced as an intervention, where \\\( \\alpha \\\) is a complex constant.

If at time \\\( t_1 \\\), a transformation \\\( h(z) = z e^{\\alpha t_1} \\\) is applied, will the resulting \\\( z(t) \\\) at time \\\( T > t_1 \\\) have its magnitude altered proportionally to \\\( e^{\\text{Re}(\\alpha) t_1} \\\)?
Explanation: The intervention \\\( h(z) \\\) scales the magnitude of any point by \\\( e^{\\text{Re}(\\alpha) t_1} \\\), where \\\( \\text{Re}(\\alpha) \\\) is the real part of \\\( \\alpha \\\). This results in an overall change in magnitude, directly proportional to \\\( e^{\\text{Re}(\\alpha) t_1} \\\), regardless of any subsequent transformations under \\\( z(t) = z_0 e^{i\\omega t} \\\).
